did.unittitle: Urban League of Greater Muskegon Records 1943-1995, 1943-1992
did.abstract: Records of the Urban League of Greater Muskegon and its predecessor the Citizen's Recreation Association of Muskegon. Board of directors files, executive director's files, community organization department files, printed material, newspaper clippings, photographs, and miscellanea.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This record group (Donor No. 4198) has come to the library in two principal accessions, in 1964 and 1995.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Urban League of Greater Muskegon Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The forerunner of the organization that became the Urban League of Greater Muskegon was the Citizens' Recreation Association, Inc., which was incorporated in February 1944. Established as an interracial, non-profit community service organization, the Citizens' Recreation Association sought to address the education, recreation, and welfare needs of the then 500 African American citizens of the greater Muskegon area.

In 1949, the Citizens' Recreation Association affiliated with the National Urban League becoming the Urban League of Greater Muskegon. The organization is governed by a multi-racial board of governors; its mission is to promote, encourage, assist, and engage in activities designed to improve the social and economic conditions of African Americans and other minority group members in Muskegon County. In order to achieve this goal, the chapter conducts programs intended to strengthen the growth and development of the African American community. Additionally, it conducts in-depth research to identify the social welfare needs of individuals and families. The Greater Muskegon chapter works extensively with existing institutions, both public and private, to make them more aware and responsive to these needs. Finally, it mobilizes and organizes the community to work for the development of alternatives to systems that have been identified as inadequate.

Examples of services provided by the Urban League of Greater Muskegon include health services, such as AIDS prevention and information, high blood pressure detection and counseling, and sickle cell anemia detection; youth employment training programs, including vocational exploration, part-time jobs that provide training and social skills that are needed in the workplace; adult employment services and information referrals, for those seeking services not offered by the Urban League; and other community and educational services.

scopecontent.p:
The records of the Urban League of Greater Muskegon have come to the library in two principal accessions, in 1964 and 1995. Included are correspondence, minutes, reports, printed materials, and newspaper clippings documenting the work of the organization. The record group has been divided into the following series:
History/Background Information
Board of Directors
Organizational
Executive Director
Topical File
Community Organization Department
Urban League Guild of Greater Muskegon
Printed Material
Newspaper Clippings
Health Topical File
Programs
Related Organizations
Photographs

The History/Background Information series includes the League's articles of association and bylaws (1988), lists of past directors, articles of incorporation, memorabilia from the 40th anniversary of the Urban League of Greater Muskegon, and scattered issue of the chapter's different newsletters.

did.unittitle: Newsletter: Awareness and Urban News and Update, 1980-1981, 1990

scopecontent.p: Board of Directors is a series that consists of minutes and reports (1943-1962 and 1982-1983), annual reports, 1963-1990, and general administrative information (1947-1961 and 1983-1995). The annual report typically includes the following: Message from the President of the 16 member Executive Board, Executive Director's message (day to day administrator), summation and results of the year's projects, and a condensed financial report.
Organizational is a series documenting the annual meetings of the chapter and the workings of the various area committees.

The Executive Director series includes correspondence (1947-1962) as well as files for individual executive directors. There are files for Jesse Carter, Stephen Pressley, Dorothy Spurlock, Donald Everette, and Gloria White Gardner. These records help to reveal the broader extent of their duties as well as their personal involvement. As with the Board of Directors, this series contains a wide array of written communication involving various individuals and organizations detailing orders, upcoming events, and general administrative business.

did.unittitle: West-Central Michigan Regional Social Welfare Conference 1955

scopecontent.p: Community Organization Department (1947-1960) consists of reports, correspondence, and a topical file documenting various organizations and activities. This topical file also includes personnel information, press releases, and speeches.

did.unittitle: Community Organizations Council of the National Urban League 1950-1952
Coordinating Committee on Race Relations undated, 1950-1951
Geriatrics Council of Greater Muskegon undated, 1952-1961
Tenants Council of Fairview Homes undated, 1949-1951
United League of Emerson Highlands undated, 1949-1959
Urban League Guild of Greater Muskegon

scopecontent.p: The Urban League Guild of Greater Muskegon (1949-1961) includes minutes and general information.
The Printed Material (1949-1961 and 1977-1995) series contains Urban League related materials from the national office and several affiliates.

Health Topical File (1976-1993) contains extensive information dealing with AIDS, including a task force, and the Urban League of Greater Muskegon's Community Hypertension Intervention Program. Other health issues include but, are not limited to, drug education, teenage pregnancy, Wellness, the Mobile Health Fair, and Sickle Cell Anemia detection. This series also documents many of the tasks of Alecia Spigner, who was the League's Health Services Manager from 1985 to 1990. The series concludes with a comprehensive study of home health care by the West Michigan Health Systems Agency.

did.unittitle: Coalition for Diabetes Education and Minority Health 1990-1991

scopecontent.p: Programs (1980-1993; .5 linear feet) is a series that documents activities that the Urban League of Greater Muskegon has fostered, such as the voter registration drive in 1988.

did.unittitle: Historic Black Colleges and Universities Tour 1991-1992

scopecontent.p: Related Organizations (1977-1993) detail many of the organizations with which the Urban League of Greater Muskegon has had working relationships. Some of these organizations were used for referral, some aided the Urban League, and some were aided by the Urban League.

did.unittitle: Ad Hoc Committee of Concerned Citizens 1991-1992
City of Muskegon Affirmative Action Plan 1992
Harbor Lights of the City Rescue Mission 1992-1993
Muskegon County Assembly for Senior Programs 1985
National Urban League Analysis of Median Housing 1991
National Urban League Developing Family-Based Services 1988
National Urban League Minutes of the Delegate Assembly 1984
Planned Parenthood Centers of Western Michigan 1991
Pontiac Urban League Proposal for Religious Support 1988
United Way Allocation and Review Long-Range Planning 1982-1983
Women of Color Reaching Out Task Force 1991
Group portraits and snapshots of Urban League leaders, volunteers, and of the music ensemble, the Chansonettes; and snapshots of community service activities and special events.
